contentrichtext.text: {{Refimprove|date=November 2007}} [[Image:Nicholas Pocock - Woolwich Dockyard.jpg|thumb|''Woolwich Dockyard'', [[Nicholas Pocock]], 1790, [[National Maritime Museum]]]] '''Woolwich Dockyard''' was an [[England|English]] naval [[shipyard|dockyard]] founded by King [[Henry VIII of England|Henry VIII]] in 1512 to build his [[flagship]] ''[[Henri Grâce à Dieu]]'' (''Great Harry''), the largest ship of its day.<ref name="eb">[http://library.eb.co.uk/eb/article-9077452 Woolwich], Encyclopædia Britannica Online Library Edition, 2010</ref> Like its counterpart [[Deptford Dockyard]], it was probably chosen for its position - on the south bank of the tidal [[River Thames]] conveniently close to Henry's palace at [[Greenwich, London|Greenwich]]. Its facilities ultimately included two large [[dry dock]]s, a substantial basin (now used by local anglers), [[masting sheer]]s, numerous storehouses, a gatehouse and clockhouse, gun bastions, and, in later years, a large metal-working factory used to produce [[anchors]] and other iron items used in shipbuilding. [[Engineer]] [[Samuel Bentham]] was an [[apprentice]] [[shipwright]] at the dockyard during the 1770s. As ships grew bigger and the Thames began to silt up, the dockyard eventually closed in 1869.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rmg.co.uk/explore/sea-and-ships/facts/ships-and-seafarers/the-royal-dockyards-of-deptford-and-woolwich|title=The Royal Dockyards of Deptford and Woolwich|accessdate=21 August 2012}}</ref> These days all that remains are a couple of closed off docks. Less than half a [[mile]] to the south there is a [[railway station]] called [[Woolwich Dockyard railway station|Woolwich Dockyard]]. == Notable ships launched at the dockyard == *1512–14— ''[[Henri Grâce à Dieu]]'' (''Great Harry''); flagship of Henry VIII. *1608— [[English ship Ark Royal (1587)|''Anne Royal'']] - a rebuilding *1610— [[HMS Prince Royal (1610)|''Prince Royal'']] *1613— [[English ship Defiance (1590)|''Defiance'']] - a rebuilding *1615— [[English ship Merhonour (1590)|''Merhonour'']] - a rebuilding *1616— [[HMS Convertine (1616)|''Convertine'']] - originally begun as the private warship ''Destiny'' for [[Sir Walter Raleigh]] *1617— [[English ship Rainbow (1586)|''Rainbow'']] - a rebuilding *1631— [[HMS Vanguard (1631)|''Vanguard'']] - a rebuilding *1637— [[HMS Sovereign of the Seas|''Sovereign of the Seas'']]; [[first-rate]] [[ship of the line]], ordered by [[Charles I of England|Charles I]] *1670— [[HMS St Andrew (1670)|''Saint Andrew'']]; [[first-rate]] [[ship of the line]] *1751— [[HMS Dolphin (1751)|''Dolphin'']]; [[circumnavigate]]d the globe twice. *1756— [[HMS Royal George (1756)|HMS ''Royal George'']]; [[first-rate]] [[ship of the line]]; her sinking in 1782 was one of the worst disasters in Royal Navy history - around 800 lives were lost. *1805— [[HMS Ocean (1805)|HMS ''Ocean'']]; [[second-rate]] [[ship of the line]], flagship of [[Cuthbert Collingwood, 1st Baron Collingwood|Lord Collingwood]]. *1809— [[HMS Macedonian|HMS ''Macedonian'']]; [[frigate]] captured by [[USS United States (1797)|USS ''United States'']] during the [[War of 1812]]. *1818— [[HMS Talavera|HMS ''Talavera'']]; [[third-rate]] [[ship of the line]]. *1820— [[HMS Beagle|HMS ''Beagle'']]; ship used on naturalist [[Charles Darwin]]'s famous voyage. ==References== {{reflist}} {{coord|51|29|40|N|0|3|22|E|name=Woolwich Dockyard|display=title|region:GB}} [[Category:History of Greenwich]] [[Category:London docks]] [[Category:Royal Navy dockyards in England]] [[Category:Shipbuilding in London]] [[Category:Military history of London]] [[Category:Woolwich-built ships]] [[Category:Shipyards on the River Thames]] [[Category:Military in London]] [[Category:Port of London]] [[Category:Woolwich]]
